channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Libya Militia Fighting Takes Toll on Civilians, U.N. Says
item.description: Violence in Tripoli and Benghazi in recent weeks has killed hundreds of people, the United Nations said in a report that described summary executions, abductions and torture.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Former Israeli President Proposes Global Peace Initiative in Talks With Pope
item.description: Shimon Peres presented a plan to create “a sort of United Nations for religions,” based on the assumption that religion rather than nationalism is at the root of most current conflicts.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sergio Rodrigues, Father of Brazilian Furniture Design, Dies at 86
item.description: His tables, chairs and other living accessories were said to reflect the sociable, witty nature of the Brazilian national character.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER

item.title: Obama and Cameron Call on NATO to Confront ISIS
item.description: In an opinion piece in The Times of London, President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron called on the Atlantic alliance to fight the terrorist threat posed by Sunni militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain visited students at Mount Pleasant Primary School, in Newport, Wales, as leaders gathered for a NATO summit meeting on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. Report Finds Endemic Violence Against Children
item.description: One in 10 girls worldwide have been forced into a sexual act, and six in 10 children aged 2 to 14 are regularly beaten by caregivers, according to the United Nations’ children’s agency, Unicef.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Shellshocked Ukrainians Flee to a New Life in Russia
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians have found their way into Russia, clinging to promises of work, shelter, pensions and a path to citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Ukraine Leader Says He Seeks Cease-Fire to Begin on Friday
item.description: At NATO’s summit meeting, President Petro O. Poroshenko said he would seek to establish “a bilateral cease-fire” on Friday between Ukraine’s armed forces and pro-Russian separatists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama joined the leaders of NATO countries at a summit in Wales. The members of the alliance discussed the situation in Ukraine.

item.title: W.H.O. Concerned About Another Ebola Cluster in Nigeria
item.description: William Pooley contracted the disease in August while volunteering as a nurse in Sierra Leone but recovered after 10 days of treatment in London.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Michael Jacobs, an infectious diseases specialist at the Royal Free Hospital, said William Pooley had made a complete recovery from Ebola.

item.title: At War Blog: Death, Recovery and Hope at a Hospital During Drawdown
item.description: At Bagram Airfield north of Kabul, a surgeon at Craig Joint Theater Hospital makes his rounds and reflects on his service at the largest American hospital in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By BRANDON LINGLE
item.media:description: Maj. Jason Pasley, left, and Lt. Col. Jason Williams operated on a wounded man’s arm at Craig Joint Theater Hospital.

item.title: Dozens Killed as Bus Plunges Into Stream in Northern India
item.description: The bus was carrying members of a wedding party when it plunged off a mountainous road and into a deep, fast-running stream.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Iraqis Identify Prisoner as Chinese Islamist Fighter
item.description: Photographs posted by the Defense Ministry could be the first visual evidence of a Chinese citizen fighting with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: An image taken from YouTube shows what appears to be the first known Chinese jihadist, called Bo Wang, fighting with rebels in Syria.

item.title: Taliban Attack Intelligence Base in Eastern Afghanistan
item.description: The attack in Ghazni, which killed at least 14 people, was the second in less than a week on a provincial headquarters of the National Directorate of Security.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and FAZAL MUZHARY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China’s Education Gap
item.description: The school system serves to reinforce entrenched social exclusion.
item.dc:creator: By HELEN GAO

item.title: Al Qaeda Announces New Branch on Indian Subcontinent
item.description: Some analysts in India saw the announcement as a response to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a rival group that has been recruiting Indian Muslims.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: An image of the Al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahri taken from a video in which he announced the formation of an Indian branch of his militant group.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Editors Are Detained in Extortion Investigation
item.description: Eight people, including editors for a leading Chinese business publication, are accused of extorting money from companies in return for positive coverage.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A view of the Shanghai skyline. The police in Shanghai initiated the investigation of journalists suspected of extorting money from companies for positive coverage.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, Seeking Equality in Education for Disabled Migrants
item.description: School started in China this week, but one group of students was missing, say civil society groups: the disabled children of migrant workers. The groups have appealed to the government to change this.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Mentally disabled children undergoing rehabilitation through storytelling at the Xining Orphan and Disabled Children Welfare Center in Qinghai Province. A group of civil society organizations is calling for better education for such children.

item.title: Obama and Cameron Call on NATO to Confront ISIS
item.description: In an opinion piece in The Times of London, President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron called on the Atlantic alliance to fight the terrorist threat posed by Sunni militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain visited students at Mount Pleasant Primary School, in Newport, Wales, as leaders gathered for a NATO summit meeting on Thursday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Israel’s Lessons From the Gaza Wars
item.description: The continued use of force won’t bring security. The key to peace clearly lies in the creation of a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: By ALI JARBAWI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Church for the Poor
item.description: Pope Francis is reversing the Vatican's Cold War stance against liberation theology.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VALLELY

item.title: In Southeast Asia, Indonesia Becomes a Role Model for Democracy
item.description: The presidential election came to a peaceful end, reinforcing the nation’s democratic transfer of power in a region where such transitions are increasingly rare.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Outgoing Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, left, shook hands with President-elect Joko Widodo in Bali.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chekhov’s ‘The Seagull,’ Adapted and Updated for Beijing
item.description: “The Seagull and Other Birds” is set to open in Beijing on Thursday at the National Center of the Performing Arts, in a wild, global version that takes in Chekhov’s Russia and the Chinese and Korean television of today.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A rehearsal of ‘‘The Seagull and Other Birds,’’ an adaptation of Anton Chekhov’s ‘‘The Seagull’’ that is part of the 2014 Beijing Fringe Festival.

item.title: W.H.O. Leader Describes the Agency’s Ebola Operations
item.description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, described how the agency offered assistance in the Ebola crisis.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the W.H.O., after a meeting in New York on Monday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: No More Dams on the Mekong
item.description: The environmental and socioeconomic costs of major hydropower projects on the river are too great.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID ROBERTS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Authorities Search for Whereabouts of Toxic Capsules
item.description: An investigation is underway to track the whereabouts of 90 million drug capsules contaminated with the heavy metal chromium that were released to the market in China earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Video Feature: Video Feature: Surviving an ISIS Massacre [includes graphic images]
item.description: Ali Hussein Kadhim, an Iraqi soldier, was captured with hundreds of other soldiers by Sunni militants in June. As a Shiite, he was marked for death. [Video includes graphic images.]
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: An image taken from a video posted by militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria shows insurgents leading away captured Iraqi soldiers in June in Tikrit. Mr. Kadhim said he was among this group.
